chapterMeaning: The Yoga of the Vision of the Universal Form
sanskrit:
मत्कर्मकृन्मत्परमो मद्भक्तः सङ्गवर्जितः।
निर्वैरः सर्वभूतेषु यः स मामेति पाण्डव॥
transliteration:
mat-karma-kṛn mat-paramo mad-bhaktaḥ saṅga-varjitaḥ |
nirvairaḥ sarva-bhūteṣu yaḥ sa mām eti pāṇḍava ||
translation: One who performs all actions for Me, who regards Me as the Supreme Goal, who is devoted to Me, who is free from attachment, and who bears enmity toward none—such a person, O Arjuna, comes to Me.
commentary:
This concluding verse of Chapter 11 provides a beautiful synthesis of the path to reach the Supreme. After revealing His cosmic form and explaining the nature of divine vision, Krishna now describes the practical means by which a devotee can attain Him. The verse outlines five essential qualities: performing actions as offerings to God (mat-karma-kṛt), considering God as the ultimate goal (mat-paramaḥ), pure devotion (mad-bhaktaḥ), freedom from worldly attachments (saṅga-varjitaḥ), and universal goodwill without enmity (nirvairaḥ sarva-bhūteṣu).

This verse serves as a perfect transition from the overwhelming vision of the Universal Form back to the practical path of devotion. While the cosmic vision revealed God's infinite and terrifying aspects, this verse emphasizes that the Supreme can be reached through simple, sincere devotion combined with selfless action and pure heart. The emphasis on being free from enmity toward all beings reflects the understanding that one who truly sees God in all cannot harbor hatred toward any creature. This teaching integrates karma yoga (selfless action), bhakti yoga (devotion), and jnana yoga (wisdom) into a unified path, showing that true devotion must manifest in one's actions and attitudes toward all beings.
speaker: Krishna
